title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test (CMH) inferential test association two binary variables, controlling third confounding nominal variable (Cochran 1954; Mantel Haenszel 1959). Essentially, CMH test examines weighted association set 2 ×\times 2 tables. common odds ratio relating test statistic can also generated (Mantel Haenszel 1959). CMH test common technique field biostatistics, often used case-control studies. introduction briefly describes terminology concepts surrounding stratified tables. Examples given show basic techniques working multidimensional tables R. Functionality samplesizeCMH package highlighted may augment analysis.

title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Consider contingency table comparing XX YY fixed level ZZ. cross-section three-way table examining one level ZZ called partial table. hand, combined counts XX YY across levels ZZ, id est simple two-way contingency table ignoring ZZ, produce marginal table. concepts described depth Agresti (2002, sec. 2.7.1).

title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: use Titanic dataset datasets package illustrate. dataset four-dimensional table includes Class (1st, 2nd, 3rd, Crew), Sex (Male, Female), Age (Child, Adult), Survival (, Yes) passengers 1912 maritime disaster. Use help("Titanic", "datasets") find information. illustration, remove age dimension, transforming four-dimensional table three-dimensional table. Let XX = sex, YY = survival, ZZ = class. dimensionality reduction accomplished using margin.table() function base package. tables partial table: survival sex fixed level class. tables can flattened easier viewing using ftable() function stats package (shown). code shows marginal table survival sex, ignoring class. dimensionality reduced using margin.table() function. aside, may get table, row, column proportions using prop.table() function. Titanic dataset multidimensional table, must first transformed two-dimensional table using margin.table() (performed ). Failure produce unexpected results.
code: data(Titanic, package = "datasets") str(Titanic) ##  'table' num [1:4, 1:2, 1:2, 1:2] 0 0 35 0 0 0 17 0 118 154 ... ##  - attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 4 ##   ..$ Class   : chr [1:4] "1st" "2nd" "3rd" "Crew" ##   ..$ Sex     : chr [1:2] "Male" "Female" ##   ..$ Age     : chr [1:2] "Child" "Adult" ##   ..$ Survived: chr [1:2] "No" "Yes" partial_tables <- margin.table(Titanic, c(2,4,1)) partial_tables ## , , Class = 1st ##  ##         Survived ## Sex       No Yes ##   Male   118  62 ##   Female   4 141 ##  ## , , Class = 2nd ##  ##         Survived ## Sex       No Yes ##   Male   154  25 ##   Female  13  93 ##  ## , , Class = 3rd ##  ##         Survived ## Sex       No Yes ##   Male   422  88 ##   Female 106  90 ##  ## , , Class = Crew ##  ##         Survived ## Sex       No Yes ##   Male   670 192 ##   Female   3  20 marginal_table <- margin.table(Titanic, c(2,4)) marginal_table ##         Survived ## Sex        No  Yes ##   Male   1364  367 ##   Female  126  344 # Table proportions prop.table(marginal_table) ##         Survived ## Sex              No        Yes ##   Male   0.61971831 0.16674239 ##   Female 0.05724671 0.15629259 # Row proportions prop.table(marginal_table, 1) ##         Survived ## Sex             No       Yes ##   Male   0.7879838 0.2120162 ##   Female 0.2680851 0.7319149 # Column proportions prop.table(marginal_table, 2) ##         Survived ## Sex              No        Yes ##   Male   0.91543624 0.51617440 ##   Female 0.08456376 0.48382560

what: Conditional, Marginal, and Common Odds Ratios
title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: comparing variables XX YY fixed jj level ZZ, may use conditional odds ratio, described Agresti (2002, sec. 2.7.4), represent point estimate association variables. denote θXY(j)\theta_{XY(j)}. marginal odds ratio refer odds ratio XX YY generated marginal table. follows marginal odds ratio denoted θXY\theta_{XY}. odds ratio estimate (θ̂\hat\theta) can calculated table matrix using samplesizeCMH package using odds.ratio() function. odds.ratio() function can take either table frequencies, probabilities, percents, results algebraically equivalent.

previous_headings: Conditional, Marginal, and Common Odds Ratios
what: Demonstration of Algebraic Equivalence of using Frequencies or Proportions in Odds Ratio Calculation
title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Using proportions, see ratio row odds o1o_1 o2o_2 estimated. θ̂=ô1ô2=π̂11/π̂12π̂21/π̂22=π̂11π̂22π̂12π̂21. \hat{\theta}= \frac{\hat{o}_1}{\hat{o}_2} = \frac{\hat{\pi}_{11} / \hat{\pi}_{12}}{\hat{\pi}_{21} / \hat{\pi}_{22}} = \frac{\hat{\pi}_{11}\hat{\pi}_{22}}{\hat{\pi}_{12}\hat{\pi}_{21}}. since row odds estimates related row proportions, turn related cell counts following, ô=π̂11−π̂1=π̂1π̂2=n1/n+n2/n+=n1n2, \hat{o} = \frac{\hat{\pi}_1}{1 - \hat{\pi}_1} = \frac{\hat{\pi}_1}{\hat{\pi}_2} = \frac{n_1 / n_+}{n_2 / n_+} = \frac{n_1}{n_2}, odds estimate, defined π̂1π̂2\frac{\hat{\pi}_1}{\hat{\pi}_2}, equivalent n1n2\frac{n_1}{n_2}. Therefore, θ̂=π̂11π̂22π̂12π̂21=n11n22n12n21. \hat{\theta}= \frac{\hat{\pi}_{11}\hat{\pi}_{22}}{\hat{\pi}_{12}\hat{\pi}_{21}} = \frac{n_{11}n_{22}}{n_{12}n_{21}}.

previous_headings: Conditional, Marginal, and Common Odds Ratios
title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Let’s first look marginal odds ratio survival sex using Titanic data. conditional odds ratios can calculated using partial tables. Obviously informative simple marginal odds ratio. Based see , survival sex appears vary widely class, women 1st class survive much higher rate men, whereas 3rd class women slightly better chance survival male counterparts. can produce common (weighted) odds ratio using mantelhaen.test() stats package. Note differs slightly marginal odds ratio since takes account differential sizes partial table.
code: library(samplesizeCMH)  odds.ratio(marginal_table) ## [1] 10.14697 apply(partial_tables, 3, odds.ratio) ##       1st       2nd       3rd      Crew  ## 67.088710 44.067692  4.071612 23.263889 mantelhaen.test(partial_tables) ##  ##  Mantel-Haenszel chi-squared test with continuity correction ##  ## data:  partial_tables ## Mantel-Haenszel X-squared = 360.33, df = 1, p-value < 2.2e-16 ## alternative hypothesis: true common odds ratio is not equal to 1 ## 95 percent confidence interval: ##   8.232629 14.185153 ## sample estimates: ## common odds ratio  ##          10.80653

title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: term conditional association refers association XX YY variables conditional level ZZ. Likewise, marginal association refers overall association XX YY ignoring ZZ. finding conditional association imply marginal association, vice-versa. use CMH test control stratifying variable analysis serves avoid well-documented phenomenon Simpson’s Paradox statistical significance may found considering association two variables, significance may found considering stratification. Likewise, reverse situation may arise association may found binary variables, may observed third variable introduced. Refer Agresti (2002, sec. 2.7.3) information content section.

title: Introduction to the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Homogeneous association odds ratios binary variables XX YY equal jj levels variable ZZ, θXY(1)=θXY(2)=...=θXY(j).\theta_{XY(1)}=\theta_{XY(2)}=...=\theta_{XY(j)}.(Agresti 2002, sec. 2.7.6) Breslow-Day test can used check null hypothesis odds ratios equal. Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test can thought special case Breslow-Day test wherein common odds ratio assumed 1 (however, calculations equivalent). Using Titanic data, can perform Breslow-Day test using BreslowDayTest() DescTools package. Note near agreement output mantelhaen.test() section .
code: library(DescTools)  BreslowDayTest(x = partial_tables, OR = 1) ##  ##  Breslow-Day test on Homogeneity of Odds Ratios ##  ## data:  partial_tables ## X-squared = 397.54, df = 3, p-value < 2.2e-16

title: Power Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: use Titanic dataset datasets package demonstrate post hoc power calculation. dataset explored greater detail introductory vignette. Let XX = sex, YY = survival, ZZ = class. Just performed introductory vignette, load data create set partial tables stratified fixed levels class.
code: data(Titanic, package = "datasets") partial_tables <- margin.table(Titanic, c(2, 4, 1)) ftable(partial_tables) ##                 Class 1st 2nd 3rd Crew ## Sex    Survived                        ## Male   No             118 154 422  670 ##        Yes             62  25  88  192 ## Female No               4  13 106    3 ##        Yes            141  93  90   20

title: Power Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: saw introductory vignette, performing CMH test partial tables shows strong evidence common odds ratio greater one. indicate association sex survival, even accounting confounding class variable.
code: mantelhaen.test(partial_tables) ##  ##  Mantel-Haenszel chi-squared test with continuity correction ##  ## data:  partial_tables ## Mantel-Haenszel X-squared = 360.33, df = 1, p-value < 2.2e-16 ## alternative hypothesis: true common odds ratio is not equal to 1 ## 95 percent confidence interval: ##   8.232629 14.185153 ## sample estimates: ## common odds ratio  ##          10.80653

title: Power Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Now ’ve established association, ’ll use power.cmh.test() function calculate probability rejection null hypothesis true result. Perhaps unsurprisingly, power test approaches 100%.
code: library(samplesizeCMH)  # Pre-computing counts (for readability) column_props <- apply(partial_tables, 3, prop.table, 2) props_male_survived_no <- column_props[1, ] props_male_survived_yes <- column_props[3, ] n_total_by_class <- apply(partial_tables, 3, sum) n_total_by_class_survived_no <- apply(partial_tables[, 1, ], 2, sum) n_total <- sum(Titanic)  power.cmh.test(   p1 = props_male_survived_no,   p2 = props_male_survived_yes,   N = n_total,   power = NULL,   s = n_total_by_class_survived_no / n_total_by_class,   t = n_total_by_class / n_total ) ## NOTE: Effect size ('theta') is not consistent between strata. ## Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test ##  ##                  N = 2201 ##        Effective N = 2201 ## Significance level = 0.05 ##              Power = 1 ##        Alternative = two.sided ##  ## Number of subjects per each group: ## ______________________________________ ## Group   |     1      2      3      4  ## ====================================== ## Case    |   122    167    528    673  ## Control |   203    118    178    212  ##  ## CALL:  ## power.cmh.test(p1 = props_male_survived_no, p2 = props_male_survived_yes,  ##     N = n_total, power = NULL, s = n_total_by_class_survived_no/n_total_by_class,  ##     t = n_total_by_class/n_total)

what: Power and Effect Size in a Negative Result
title: Power Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: make sense calculate power study null hypothesis rejected. However, may interest researcher determine minimum effect size detected, given sample size study specified power. use example Nurses’ Health Study explored Munoz Rosner (1984). study looked link oral contraceptives breast cancer, stratified age (Barton et al. 1980; Hennekens et al. 1984). data illustration included samplesizeCMH package. , shown Hennekens et al. (1984), Mantel-Haenszel test shows non-significant results, common odds ratio approximately equal 1. question now effect size detectable effect truly exist data. say, effect size prepared correctly detect given data specified significance level power? can test wide range effect sizes see effect size crosses adequate power. accomplish , partially apply power.cmh.test() function vectorize theta. Passing vector thetas new function provide us vector computed powers. Although simple () loop suffice generate power curve, additional benefit associated creation partially applied function—see later can used compute exact effect size yield 90% power. Using function , may create power curve.  can see , 90% power achieved common odds ratio estimated approximately 1.25. compute exact effect size, employ stats::uniroot() function.
code: data(contraceptives, package = "samplesizeCMH") ftable(contraceptives) ##                            Age Group <= 34 35 - 39 40 - 44 45 - 49 50 - 55 ## OC Usage    Disease Status                                                 ## Exposed     Case                        31      57      69      86      30 ##             Control                    363     521     760     725     272 ## Not Exposed Case                        40     107     196     241     132 ##             Control                    327    1146    1914    2503    1370 mantelhaen.test(contraceptives) ##  ##  Mantel-Haenszel chi-squared test with continuity correction ##  ## data:  contraceptives ## Mantel-Haenszel X-squared = 0.33106, df = 1, p-value = 0.565 ## alternative hypothesis: true common odds ratio is not equal to 1 ## 95 percent confidence interval: ##  0.902928 1.214722 ## sample estimates: ## common odds ratio  ##          1.047285 partially_apply_power_func <-   function(...) function(theta) power.cmh.test(theta = theta, ...)[["power"]]  n_control_exposed <- contraceptives[1, 2, ] n_control_total <- apply(contraceptives[, 2, ], 2, sum) n_total_by_age <- apply(contraceptives, 3, sum) n_total <- sum(contraceptives)  partial_power_func <- partially_apply_power_func(   p2 = n_control_exposed / n_control_total,   N = n_total,   power = NULL,   s = 1/11,   t = n_total_by_age / n_total,   alternative = "greater" )  vectorized_power_func <- Vectorize(partial_power_func, "theta", SIMPLIFY = TRUE) thetas <- seq(1.05, 1.5, 0.05) powers <- vectorized_power_func(thetas)  plot(y = powers, x = thetas, main = "Power curve as a function of effect size") abline(h = 0.95, col = "gold") abline(h = 0.90, col = "red") abline(h = 0.80, col = "blue")  legend(   "bottomright",    legend = c("95%", "90%", "80%"),    col = c("gold", "red", "blue"),   bty = "n",   lty = 1L,   title = "Power level"   ) target_power <- 0.90 first_over <- which.min(powers <= target_power) interval <- thetas[c(first_over - 1, first_over)] uniroot(function(theta) partial_power_func(theta) - target_power, interval)$root ## [1] 1.248515

title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: first method estimate sample size CMH test introduced Gail (1973) using least squares method. Munoz Rosner (1984) later produced sample size estimators useful special case margins fixed. However, often case retrospective case-control designs. , Woolson, Bean, Rojas (1986) introduced calculation using weighted difference two binomial distributions, assumes one margin fixed. corroborated Wittes Wallenstein (1987) paper year later. Later still, Nam (1992) improved upon calculation introducing coefficient address continuity corrected CMH tests. methods included package based calculations derived Woolson, Bean, Rojas (1986) uncorrected statistics Nam (1992) continuity corrected statistics. slightly precise power calculation used based Wittes Wallenstein (1987), functionally equivalent calculation Woolson, Bean, Rojas (1986).

title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Starting example first used Woolson, Bean, Rojas (1986) revisited Nam (1992), explore usage central function samplesizeCMH package, power.cmh.test() function. case–control study looked whether association colon cancer chlorinated drinking water among males Iowa, stratified age. four age categories, 20–54 years, 55–69 years, 70–79 years, 80–84 years; therefore number levels stratifying variable JJ = 4. relative proportion age group total sample follows: t1t_1 = 0.10, t2t_2 = 0.40, t3t_3 = 0.35, t4t_4 = 0.15. National Collaborative Bladder Cancer Study showed exposure rate controls age stratum, denoted π2j\pi_{2j} (subscript ‘2’ indicates second column proportions jj stratum), π21\pi_{21} = 0.75, π22\pi_{22} = 0.70, π23\pi_{23} = 0.65, π24\pi_{24} = 0.60. Level significance set 0.05 desired power 90% effect size 3. matched equal number cases controls stratum, .e., s1=s2=s3=s4=s_1=s_2=s_3=s_4= 0.5.

title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: go several variations experimental design explore usage power.cmh.test() function.

title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Suppose researchers first decided use original CMH calculation, ignoring contnuity correction. , parameter correct set FALSE. see researcher put control exposure proportions vector (p2), effect size given (theta), vector relative stratum sizes assigned (t). Since equal numbers cases controls group, s parameter required. p1 p2 one proportions theta required carry calculation. number strata (JJ) inferred maximum vector length p1, p2, theta. Note detail = FALSE parameter passed print method reduce output.
code: library(samplesizeCMH)  sample_size_uncorrected <- power.cmh.test(   p2 = c(0.75,0.70,0.65,0.60),   theta = 3,   power = 0.9,   t = c(0.10,0.40,0.35,0.15),   alternative = "greater",   correct = FALSE )  print(sample_size_uncorrected, detail = FALSE) ## Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test ##  ##                  N = 171 ##        Effective N = 174 ## Significance level = 0.05 ##              Power = 0.9 ##        Alternative = greater ##  ## CALL:  ## power.cmh.test(p2 = c(0.75, 0.7, 0.65, 0.6), theta = 3, power = 0.9,  ##     alternative = "greater", t = c(0.1, 0.4, 0.35, 0.15), correct = FALSE)

title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: reading, researcher now determined continuity correction appropriate performing CMH test (default mantaelhaen.test() correct = TRUE). correct parameter code flipped TRUE take continuity correction account. see N increased ≈\approx 12%, expected continuity correction taken account. n.frac option used get fractional n’s, rather rounding next whole number.
code: sample_size_corrected <- power.cmh.test(   p2 = c(0.75,0.70,0.65,0.60),   theta = 3,   power = 0.9,   t = c(0.10,0.40,0.35,0.15),   alternative = "greater",   correct = TRUE )  print(sample_size_corrected, n.frac = TRUE) ## Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test ##  ##                  N = 191.538 ##        Effective N = 196 ## Significance level = 0.05 ##              Power = 0.9 ##        Alternative = greater ##  ## Number of subjects per each group: ## ______________________________________________ ## Group   |       1        2        3        4  ## ============================================== ## Case    |    9.58    38.31    33.52    14.37  ## Control |    9.58    38.31    33.52    14.37  ##  ## CALL:  ## power.cmh.test(p2 = c(0.75, 0.7, 0.65, 0.6), theta = 3, power = 0.9,  ##     alternative = "greater", t = c(0.1, 0.4, 0.35, 0.15), correct = TRUE)

what: Unequal Numbers of Cases and Controls
title: Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Consider now researcher performed preparatory work found number cases available much fewer number available controls. fact, difficult find cases meet inclusion criteria, relatively easy find controls meet inclusion criteria. Wanting leverage available data, adjustment made sample size calculation performed earlier including s parameter. design now supposes two controls matched case. Note effective N increased 24 subjects. CMH test optimum efficiency s balanced. Therefore, altering case/control ratio implemented compelling reason , difficulty finding cases prohibitive costs.
code: power.cmh.test(   p2 = c(0.75,0.70,0.65,0.60),   s = 1/3,   theta = 3,   power = 0.9,   t = c(0.10,0.40,0.35,0.15),   alternative = "greater",   correct = TRUE ) ## Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test ##  ##                  N = 217 ##        Effective N = 220 ## Significance level = 0.05 ##              Power = 0.9 ##        Alternative = greater ##  ## Number of subjects per each group: ## ______________________________________ ## Group   |     1      2      3      4  ## ====================================== ## Case    |     8     29     26     11  ## Control |    15     58     51     22  ##  ## CALL:  ## power.cmh.test(p2 = c(0.75, 0.7, 0.65, 0.6), theta = 3, power = 0.9,  ##     alternative = "greater", s = 1/3, t = c(0.1, 0.4, 0.35, 0.15),  ##     correct = TRUE)

Using effect.size() function, can use expected exposure rate control estimate expected exposure rate cases. can now use fill remainder table. determine odds exposure two groups, can use prop2odds(). can also use either row column proportions calculate odds ratio 2 ×\times 2 table. see brings us back specified effect size, theta = 3, used sample size calculaion. several peripheral functions package interconvert proportions, odds, relative risk, odds ratios. Use help("odds..proportions", "samplesizeCMH") find .

title: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test (CMH) inferential test association two binary variables, controlling third confounding nominal variable. Two variables interest, X Y, compared level confounder variable Z results combined, creating common odds ratio. Essentially, CMH test examines weighted association X Y. CMH test common technique field biostatistics, often used case-control studies.

title: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Given target power researcher like achieve, calculation can performed order estimate appropriate number subjects study. power.cmh.test function calculates required number subjects per group achieve specified power Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test.

title: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test
text: Researchers interested estimating probability detecting true positive result inferential test must perform power calculation using known sample size, effect size, significance level, et cetera. power.cmh.test function can compute power CMH test, given parameters experiment.

title: Interconvert odds and proportion values — odds.and.proportions
code: # Convert proportions of 0 through 1 to odds props <- seq(0,1,0.1) prop2odds(props) #>  [1] 0.0000000 0.1111111 0.2500000 0.4285714 0.6666667 1.0000000 1.5000000 #>  [8] 2.3333333 4.0000000 9.0000000       Inf  # Convert odds to proportions odds2prop(1:3) #> [1] 0.5000000 0.6666667 0.7500000  # Raise a proportion by an effect size theta effect.size(0.5, 2) #> [1] 0.6666667  # Find the odds ratio between two proportions props2theta(0.75, 0.5) #> [1] 3

text: Paul W. Egeler, M.S.

title: Create an odds ratio estimate from a 2-by-2 table of frequencies or proportions — odds.ratio
code: # Load in Titanic data from datasets package data(Titanic, package = "datasets")  # Get marginal table of survival by sex marginal_table <- margin.table(Titanic, c(2,4)) marginal_table #>         Survived #> Sex        No  Yes #>   Male   1364  367 #>   Female  126  344  # Compute odds ratio of marginal table odds.ratio(marginal_table) #> [1] 10.14697  # Get partial tables of survival by sex, stratified by class partial_tables <- margin.table(Titanic, c(2,4,1)) partial_tables #> , , Class = 1st #>  #>         Survived #> Sex       No Yes #>   Male   118  62 #>   Female   4 141 #>  #> , , Class = 2nd #>  #>         Survived #> Sex       No Yes #>   Male   154  25 #>   Female  13  93 #>  #> , , Class = 3rd #>  #>         Survived #> Sex       No Yes #>   Male   422  88 #>   Female 106  90 #>  #> , , Class = Crew #>  #>         Survived #> Sex       No Yes #>   Male   670 192 #>   Female   3  20 #>   # Compute odds ratio of each partial table apply(partial_tables, 3, odds.ratio) #>       1st       2nd       3rd      Crew  #> 67.088710 44.067692  4.071612 23.263889

what: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: Compute post-hoc power required number subjects Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test association J stratified 2 x 2 tables.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
code: power.cmh.test(   p1 = NULL,   p2 = NULL,   theta = NULL,   N = NULL,   sig.level = 0.05,   power = 0.8,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   s = 0.5,   t = 1/J,   correct = TRUE )

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: p1 Vector proportions J case groups. p2 Vector proportions J control groups. theta Vector odds ratios relating J 2 x 2 tables. N Total number subjects. sig.level Significance level (Type error probability). power Power test (1 minus Type II error probability). alternative Two- one-sided test. one-sided, direction association must defined (less 1 greater 1). Can abbreviated. s Proportion (weight) case versus control J stratum. t Proportion (weight) total number cases J stratum. correct Logical indicating whether apply continuity correction.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: object class "power.cmh": list original arguments calculated sample size power. Also included vectors n's per group, indicator whether continuity correction used, original function call, N.effective. vectors n's per group, n1 n2, fractional n's required achieve final total N specified calculation satisfying constraints s t. However, effective N, given requirement cell counts populated whole numbers provided N.effective. default, print method set n.frac = FALSE, round cell n nearest whole number.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: sample size calculation based derivations described Woolson et al. (1986). designed case-control studies one margin fixed. method "based Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel statistic expressed weighted difference binomial proportions." Continuity corrected sample size described Nam's 1992 paper. uses weighted binomial sample size calculation described Woolson et al. (1986) enhanced use continuity corrected Cochran's test. Power calculations based writings Wittes Wallenstein (1987). functionally equivalent derivations sample size calculation described Woolson others Nam, slightly added precision. Terminology symbolic conventions borrowed Woolson et al. (1986). p1 group dubbed Case group p2 group called Control group.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: calculate power, power parameter must set NULL. calculate sample size, N parameter must set NULL. J number groups inferred maximum length p1, p2, theta. Effect size must specified using one following combinations arguments. case control proportion vectors, ex., p1 p2 theta = NULL. One proportion vector effect size, ex., p1 theta p2 = NULL, p2 theta p1 = NULL.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: Gail, M. (1973). "determination sample sizes trials involving several 2 x 2 tables." Journal Chronic Disease 26: 669-673. Munoz, . B. Rosner. (1984). "Power sample size collection 2 x 2 tables." Biometrics 40: 995-1004. Nam, J. (1992). "Sample size determination case-control studies comparison stratified unstratified analyses." Biometrics 48: 389-395. Wittes, J. S. Wallenstein. (1987). "power Mantel-Haenszel test." Journal American Statistical Association 82: 1104-1109. Woolson, R. F., Bean, J. ., P. B. Rojas. (1986). "Sample size case-control studies using Cochran's statistic." Biometrics 42: 927-932.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
text: Paul W. Egeler, M.S.

title: Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test — power.cmh.test
code: # From "Sample size determination for case-control studies and the comparison # of stratified and unstratified analyses", (Nam 1992). See references.  # Uncorrected sample size estimate first introduced # by Woolson and others in 1986 sample_size_uncorrected <- power.cmh.test(   p2 = c(0.75,0.70,0.65,0.60),   theta = 3,   power = 0.9,   t = c(0.10,0.40,0.35,0.15),   alternative = "greater",   correct = FALSE )  print(sample_size_uncorrected, detail = FALSE) #> Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test #>  #>                  N = 171 #>        Effective N = 174 #> Significance level = 0.05 #>              Power = 0.9 #>        Alternative = greater #>  #> CALL:  #> power.cmh.test(p2 = c(0.75, 0.7, 0.65, 0.6), theta = 3, power = 0.9,  #>     alternative = "greater", t = c(0.1, 0.4, 0.35, 0.15), correct = FALSE)  # We see that the N is 171, the same as calculated by Nam sample_size_uncorrected$N #> [1] 170.7412   # Continuity corrected sample size estimate added by Nam sample_size_corrected <- power.cmh.test(   p2 = c(0.75,0.70,0.65,0.60),   theta = 3,   power = 0.9,   t = c(0.10,0.40,0.35,0.15),   alternative = "greater",   correct = TRUE )  print(sample_size_corrected, n.frac = TRUE) #> Power and sample size calculation for the Cochran Mantel Haenszel test #>  #>                  N = 191.538 #>        Effective N = 196 #> Significance level = 0.05 #>              Power = 0.9 #>        Alternative = greater #>  #> Number of subjects per each group: #> ______________________________________________ #> Group   |       1        2        3        4  #> ============================================== #> Case    |    9.58    38.31    33.52    14.37  #> Control |    9.58    38.31    33.52    14.37  #>  #> CALL:  #> power.cmh.test(p2 = c(0.75, 0.7, 0.65, 0.6), theta = 3, power = 0.9,  #>     alternative = "greater", t = c(0.1, 0.4, 0.35, 0.15), correct = TRUE)  # We see that the N is indeed equal to that which is reported in the paper sample_size_corrected$N #> [1] 191.538

what: samplesizeCMH: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test — samplesizeCMH
title: samplesizeCMH: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test — samplesizeCMH
text: package provides functions relating power sample size calculation CMH test. also several helper functions interconverting probability, odds, relative risk, odds ratio values.

title: samplesizeCMH: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test — samplesizeCMH
text: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test (CMH) inferential test association two binary variables, controlling third confounding nominal variable. Two variables interest, X Y, compared level confounder variable Z results combined, creating common odds ratio. Essentially, CMH test examines weighted association X Y. CMH test common technique field biostatistics, often used case-control studies.

title: samplesizeCMH: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test — samplesizeCMH
text: Given target power researcher like achieve, calculation can performed order estimate appropriate number subjects study. power.cmh.test function calculates required number subjects per group achieve specified power Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test.

title: samplesizeCMH: Power and Sample Size Calculation for the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Test — samplesizeCMH
text: Researchers interested estimating probability detecting true positive result inferential test must perform power calculation using known sample size, effect size, significance level, et cetera. power.cmh.test function can compute power CMH test, given parameters experiment.

title: samplesizeCMH Version 0.0.4
text: Updated power vignette show compute exact effect size given power using stats::uniroot() function.
